## Community Coordinated Modeling Center Database Of Notifications, Knowledge, Information ( CCMC DONKI )
## Message Type: Space Weather Notification - Interplanetary Shock
##
## Message Issue Date: 2021-10-31T12:31:03Z
## Message ID: 20211031-AL-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Significant interplanetary shock detected by DSCOVR at L1 at 2021-10-31T09:13Z. 

The shock may be caused by CME with ID 2021-10-28T15:53:00-CME-001 (see notifications 20211028-AL-010, 20211029-AL-001, 20211029-AL-002). Possible geomagnetic storm expected.

Activity ID: 2021-10-31T09:13:00-IPS-001.

## Notes:

## Community Coordinated Modeling Center Database Of Notifications, Knowledge, Information ( CCMC DONKI )
## Message Type: Space Weather Notification - SEP
##
## Message Issue Date: 2021-10-29T17:01:10Z
## Message ID: 20211029-AL-004
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Solar energetic particle event detected by SOHO.  The flux of one or more of the >15.8 MeV protons channels exceeds 10^(-1) pfu/MeV starting at 2021-10-28T17:39Z.

NASA spacecraft at MEO, GEO and other high-altitude orbits and high-inclination LEO can be impacted.

Activity ID: 2021-10-28T17:39:00-SEP-001.

## Notes: 

This SEP event detected by SOHO in both the 15.8-39.8 MeV and 28.2-50.1 MeV protons channels (2021-10-28T17:39:00-SEP-001 and 2021-10-28T20:44:00-SEP-001) is associated with X1.0 flare with ID 2021-10-28T15:17:00-FLR-001 which peaked at 2021-10-28T15:35Z from Active Region 12887 (see notifications 20211028-AL-001, 20211028-AL-002) and O-type CME with ID 2021-10-28T15:53:00-CME-001 (see notifications 20211028-AL-010, 20211029-AL-001, 20211029-AL-002).

There were also SEP events detected by GOES >10 MeV (2021-10-28T17:40:00-SEP-001, see notifications 20211028-AL-008 and 20211028-AL-009), GOES >100 MeV (2021-10-28T16:35:00-SEP-001, see notifications 20211028-AL-004, 20211028-AL-005, 20211028-AL-007), and STEREO A 13-100 MeV (2021-10-28T16:16:00-SEP-001, see notifications 20211028-AL-003 and 20211028-AL-006) associated with the X1.0 flare and O-type CME listed above.

## Community Coordinated Modeling Center Database Of Notifications, Knowledge, Information ( CCMC DONKI )
## Message Type: Space Weather Notification - CME update (ensemble) (STEREO A, STEREO B, Missions Near Earth)
##
## Message Issue Date: 2021-10-29T12:18:14Z
## Message ID: 20211029-AL-002
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

BETA PRODUCT. ENSEMBLE PRODUCT IS STILL IN DEVELOPMENT MODE. PLEASE LET US KNOW IF YOU HAVE ANY SUGGESTIONS FOR MODIFICATIONS.  

Ensemble modeling update on CMEs with ID 2021-10-28T15:53:00-CME-001 (see previous notification 20211029-AL-001, 20211028-AL-10). Based on analysis by the Moon to Mars Space Weather Office and heliospheric ensemble modeling carried out at the Community Coordinated Modeling Center, it is estimated that the CME may impact STEREO A and STEREO B. For 48 ensemble members (see notes section), simulations indicate that the leading edge of the CME will reach:

- STEREO A between about 2021-10-30T17:04Z and 2021-10-31T15:53Z (average arrival 2021-10-31T01:53Z) for 100% of simulations.
- STEREO B between about 2021-10-30T15:25Z and 2021-10-31T04:14Z (average arrival 2021-10-30T22:03Z) for 100% of simulations.

Additionally the CME is estimated to reach NASA missions near Earth between about 2021-10-30T13:04Z and 2021-10-31T01:16Z (average arrival 2021-10-30T18:55Z) for 100% of simulations.  The ensemble-based forecast indicates that there is a 65% chance for the maximum Kp index to be in the 5-7 range (minor to strong).

Links to the ensemble details of the modeled event:
https://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/ENSEMBLE/2021-10-28_ncmes1_sims48_HILOX101/20211028_155300_ncmes1_sims48_HILOX101_anim_tim-den.gif
https://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/ENSEMBLE/2021-10-28_ncmes1_sims48_HILOX101/20211028_155300_ncmes1_sims48_HILOX101_arrival_Earth.gif
https://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/ENSEMBLE/2021-10-28_ncmes1_sims48_HILOX101/20211028_155300_ncmes1_sims48_HILOX101_Earth_stack.gif
https://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/ENSEMBLE/2021-10-28_ncmes1_sims48_HILOX101/20211028_155300_ncmes1_sims48_HILOX101_probabilistic_Kp_forecast_wdist.gif
https://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/ENSEMBLE/2021-10-28_ncmes1_sims48_HILOX101/20211028_155300_ncmes1_sims48_HILOX101_arrival_STA.gif
https://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/ENSEMBLE/2021-10-28_ncmes1_sims48_HILOX101/20211028_155300_ncmes1_sims48_HILOX101_STA_stack.gif
https://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/ENSEMBLE/2021-10-28_ncmes1_sims48_HILOX101/20211028_155300_ncmes1_sims48_HILOX101_arrival_STB.gif
https://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/ENSEMBLE/2021-10-28_ncmes1_sims48_HILOX101/20211028_155300_ncmes1_sims48_HILOX101_STB_stack.gif

## Notes:

This CME event (2021-10-28T15:53:00-CME-001) is also predicted to reach Parker Solar Probe at 2021-10-30T06:54Z and Solar Orbiter at 2021-10-30T07:07Z (plus minus 7 hours) based on previous heliospheric modeling (see notifications 20211029-AL-001, 20211028-AL-010).

This CME event (2021-10-28T15:53:00-CME-001) is associated with X1.0 flare with ID 2021-10-28T15:17:00-FLR-001 which peaked at 2021-10-28T15:35Z (see notifications 20211028-AL-001, 20211028-AL-002), SEP at STEREO A with ID 2021-10-28T16:16:00-SEP-001 (see notifications 20211028-AL-003, 20211028-AL-006), SEP at GOES-P with ID 2021-10-28T16:35:00-SEP-001 (see notifications 20211028-AL-004, 20211028-AL-005, 20211028-AL-007), SEP at GOES-P with ID 2021-10-28T17:40:00-SEP-001 (see notifications 20211028-AL-008, 20211028-AL-009), and SEP at MODEL with ID 2021-10-28T18:28:00-SEP-001.

This CME was simulated with an earlier, S-type, CME (2021-10-28T01:23:00-CME-001) detected by STEREO A at 2021-10-28T01:23Z and associated with a C1.1 flare with ID 2021-10-27T21:53:00-FLR-001 which peaked at 2021-10-27T21:59Z.

Ensemble CME modeling at M2M is performed by building sets of initial CME parameters and carrying out separate simulations for each set. This approach allows a mapping of initial CME parameter uncertainties into a statistical characterization of CME arrival times and impact at locations of interest.

Description of links: For each location, the first link shows the WSA-ENLIL+Cone model animation for the median CME input parameters, the second link shows the probabilistic distribution of predicted arrival times histogram, and the third link shows a stack plot of the WSA-ENLIL+Cone modeled magnetic field, velocity, density, and temperature for all ensemble members. For missions near Earth, a histogram of the probabilistic Kp forecast is also provided.

For the full details of the modeled event, please go here:
https://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/ENSEMBLE/2021-10-28_ncmes1_sims48_HILOX101/Detailed_results_20211028_155300_ncmes1_sims48_HILOX101.txt

## Community Coordinated Modeling Center Database Of Notifications, Knowledge, Information ( CCMC DONKI )
## Message Type: Space Weather Notification - CME update (Parker Solar Probe, Solar Orbiter, STEREO A, STEREO B, Missions Near Earth)
##
## Message Issue Date: 2021-10-29T12:07:28Z
## Message ID: 20211029-AL-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Update on CME with ID 2021-10-28T15:53:00-CME-001 (see previous notification 20211028-AL-010).  Based on preliminary analysis by the Moon to Mars Space Weather Office and heliospheric modeling carried out at NASA Community Coordinated Modeling Center, it is estimated that the CME has little or no impact on Juno or Dawn.

Previous simulations also estimate that the CME may affect Parker Solar Probe, Solar Orbiter, STEREO A and STEREO B.  The leading edge of the CME will reach Parker Solar Probe at 2021-10-30T06:54Z, Solar Orbiter at 2021-10-30T07:07Z, STEREO A at 2021-10-30T23:44Z and STEREO B at 2021-10-30T20:46Z (plus minus 7 hours). 

Previous simulation also indicates that the CME may impact NASA missions near Earth. Simulations indicate that the leading edge of the CME will reach NASA missions near Earth at about 2021-10-30T16:54Z (plus minus 7 hours). The roughly estimated expected range of the maximum Kp index is 6-8 (moderate to severe).

CME parameters are (O-type):

Start time of the event: 2021-10-28T15:53Z.

Estimated speed: ~1109 km/s.

Estimated opening half-angle: 49 deg.

Direction (lon./lat.): 0/-17 in Heliocentric Earth Equatorial coordinates.

Activity ID: 2021-10-28T15:53:00-CME-001


Links to the movies of the modeled event (includes CMEs: O-type CME 2021-10-28T15:53:00-CME-001 and S-type CME 2021-10-28T01:23:00-CME-001):

(a) 2 AU outer boundary

http://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/downloads/20211028_125900_2.0_anim.tim-vel-Stereo_A.gif
http://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/downloads/20211028_125900_2.0_ENLIL_CONE_timeline.gif

http://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/downloads/20211028_125900_2.0_ENLIL_CONE_STA_timeline.gif
http://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/downloads/20211028_125900_2.0_ENLIL_CONE_STB_timeline.gif

http://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/downloads/20211028_125900_5.5_ENLIL_CONE_Dawn_timeline.gif


## Notes: 

This CME event (2021-10-28T15:53:00-CME-001) is associated with X1.0 flare with ID 2021-10-28T15:17:00-FLR-001 which peaked at 2021-10-28T15:35Z (see notifications 20211028-AL-001, 20211028-AL-002), SEP at STEREO A with ID 2021-10-28T16:16:00-SEP-001 (see notifications 20211028-AL-003, 20211028-AL-006), SEP at GOES-P with ID 2021-10-28T16:35:00-SEP-001 (see notifications 20211028-AL-004, 20211028-AL-005, 20211028-AL-007), SEP at GOES-P with ID 2021-10-28T17:40:00-SEP-001 (see notifications 20211028-AL-008, 20211028-AL-009), and SEP at MODEL with ID 2021-10-28T18:28:00-SEP-001.

This CME was simulated with an earlier, S-type, CME (2021-10-28T01:23:00-CME-001) detected by STEREO A at 2021-10-28T01:23Z and associated with a C1.1 flare with ID 2021-10-27T21:53:00-FLR-001 which peaked at 2021-10-27T21:59Z.

SCORE CME typification system:
S-type: CMEs with speeds less than 500 km/s
C-type: Common 500-999 km/s
O-type: Occasional 1000-1999 km/s
R-type: Rare 2000-2999 km/s
ER-type: Extremely Rare >3000 km/s

## Summary:

O-type CME detected by STEREO A / SOHO. 

Start time of the event: 2021-10-28T15:53Z.

Estimated speed: ~1109 km/s.

Estimated opening half-angle: 49 deg.

Direction (lon./lat.): 0/-17 in Heliocentric Earth Equatorial coordinates.

Activity ID: 2021-10-28T15:53:00-CME-001

Based on preliminary analysis by the Moon to Mars Space Weather Office and heliospheric modeling carried out at NASA Community Coordinated Modeling Center, it is estimated that the CMEs may affect Parker Solar Probe, Solar Orbiter, STEREO A, and STEREO B.  The leading edge of the CMEs will reach Parker Solar Probe at 2021-10-30T06:54Z, Solar Orbiter at 2021-10-30T07:07Z, STEREO A at 2021-10-30T23:44Z, and STEREO B at 2021-10-30T20:46Z (plus minus 7 hours). 
  
The simulation also indicates that the CMEs may impact NASA missions near Earth. Simulations indicate that the leading edge of the CMEs will reach NASA missions near Earth at about 2021-10-30T17:15Z (plus minus 7 hours). The roughly estimated expected range of the maximum Kp index is 6-8 (moderate to severe).
   
  
Links to the movies of the modeled event (includes CMEs: O-type CME 2021-10-28T15:53:00-CME-001 and S-type CME 2021-10-28T01:23:00-CME-001):

Solar activity was at moderate levels during this reporting period with 2 M-class flares (see list below).  There were 5 C-type CMEs (see details below).   

Based on preliminary analysis by the Moon to Mars Space Weather Analysis Office and heliospheric modeling carried out at NASA Community Coordinated Modeling Center, it was estimated that the C-type CME initially observed in SOHO LASCO C2 at 2021-10-25T08:48Z may arrive as a glancing blow to Mars at 2021-10-31T15:00Z and a glancing blow to OSIRIS-REx at 2021-10-30T00:00Z (plus minus 7 hours).  It was also estimated that the combined leading edge of the two C-type CMEs initially observed in STEREO A COR2 at 2021-10-26T03:23Z and 2021-10-26T04:38Z may arrive at Parker Solar Probe at 2021-10-27T19:42Z (plus minus 7 hours) (see notification 20211027-AL-001).

Geomagnetic activity was below minor levels with Kp index (a measure of geomagnetic activity, ranging 0-9) <= 3 for the reporting period.

The > 2.0 MeV energetic electron flux detected at GOES remained below the threshold level of 1000 pfu for the entire reporting period. 

The energetic proton flux of >10 MeV protons detected at GOES and the 13-100 MeV protons at STEREO A were all at background levels for the entire reporting period. 

Space Weather Impact:
Space weather impacts on NASA spacecraft are expected to have been low this week.

## Outlook Coverage Begin Date: 2021-10-27T00:00Z

Solar activity is expected to be moderate for the upcoming week.  Currently, there are six active regions on the Earth-facing solar disk. Active Regions 12886, 12888, 12889, and 12890 have a low magnetic complexity classification and may not produce too much activity.  However, Active Region 12887, currently located at S26E15, has been somewhat active during the reporting period resulting in two S-type CMEs, and it may produce more activity for the upcoming period.  Active Region 12891, currently located at N20E78, rotated onto the Earth-facing disk on 2021-10-26 and has been active resulting into the two M-class flares mentioned above.  It may be expected for this active region to produce more activity in the upcoming week.

Geomagnetic activity is expected to be below minor levels during the outlook period.  Some enhancement may be expected due to the anticipated arrival of the S-type CME initially observed in SOHO LASCO C2 at 2021-10-25T05:36Z, which was simulated to arrive as a glancing blow to Earth around 2021-10-29T02:00Z (plus minus 7 hours).  An ensemble simulation estimated the CME to reach NASA missions near Earth between about 2021-10-28T17:41Z and 2021-10-28T17:41Z (average arrival 2021-10-28T17:41Z) for 2% of simulations.  The ensemble-based forecast indicates that there is a 100% chance for the maximum Kp index to be in the 3-4 range (below minor to below minor).

Additionally, a heliospheric ensemble model run for this CME with 48 ensemble members predicted that the leading edge of the CME will reach STEREO A between about 2021-10-20T01:35Z and 2021-10-20T01:35Z (average arrival 2021-10-20T01:35Z) for 2% of simulations, STEREO B between about 2021-10-20T15:31Z and 2021-10-21T02:38Z (average arrival 2021-10-20T19:47Z) for 54% of simulations, and NASA missions near Earth between about 2021-10-19T22:29Z and 2021-10-20T10:28Z (average arrival 2021-10-20T04:34Z) for 75% of simulations (see notification 20211018-AL-001).

Geomagnetic activity was below minor levels with Kp index (a measure of geomagnetic activity, ranging 0-9) <=4 for the reporting period. The highest value of Kp = 4 occurred during the synoptic periods of 2021-10-17T18:00Z-21:00Z, 2021-10-18T00:00Z-03:00Z, 2021-10-19T03:00Z-06:00Z, and 2021-10-19T15:00Z-21:00Z. The slightly elevated values of Kp on 2021-10-17 and 2021-10-18 may have been associated with the arrival detected by DSCOVR and ACE at L1 around 2021-10-16T00:09Z of the the S-type CME first observed in SOHO imagery around 2021-10-12T03:24Z and a possible small coronal hole high speed stream detected around 2021-10-17. The slightly elevated value of Kp on 2021-10-19 was associated with the arrival of a small coronal hole high speed stream at L1 on 2021-10-18 (see notification 20211018-AL-002). The solar wind speeds reached peak values around 420 km/s on 2021-10-20.

The > 2.0 MeV energetic electron flux detected at GOES remained below the threshold level of 1000 pfu for the entire reporting period. 

The energetic proton flux of >10 MeV protons detected at GOES and the 13-100 MeV protons at STEREO A were all at background levels for the entire reporting period.

## Summary:

Solar activity was at minor to moderate levels during this reporting period with 1 M-class flare and 2 C-type CMEs (see details below).  The M1.6 class flare peaking at 2021-10-09T06:53Z originated from active region 12882 and was associated with a halo C-type CME first seen in SOHO LASCO C2 starting at 2021-10-09T07:09Z. 

Based on preliminary analysis by the Moon to Mars Space Weather Analysis Office and heliospheric modeling carried out at NASA Community Coordinated Modeling Center, it was estimated that the leading edge or flank of the CME would reach Solar Orbiter at 2021-10-10T16:55Z, STEREO B at 2021-10-11T15:03Z, Parker Solar Probe at 2021-10-11T19:00Z, and STEREO A at 2021-10-11T22:00Z (plus minus 7 hours). The simulation also indicated that the CME may impact NASA missions near Earth at about 2021-10-11T07:50Z (plus minus 7 hours). The roughly estimated expected range of the maximum Kp index was 5-7 (minor to strong). Additionally, an ensemble model was carried out for this CME. Its leading edge was estimated to reach STEREO A between about 2021-10-11T09:14Z and 2021-10-11T22:16Z (average arrival 2021-10-11T13:47Z) for 43% of simulations, STEREO B between about 2021-10-11T13:19Z and 2021-10-11T23:30Z (average arrival 2021-10-11T18:07Z) for 100% of simulations, and was estimated to reach NASA missions near Earth between about 2021-10-11T06:13Z and 2021-10-11T15:04Z (average arrival 2021-10-11T10:23Z) for 100% of simulations.  The ensemble-based forecast indicated that there was a 74% chance for the maximum Kp index to be in the 5-7 range (minor to strong) (see notifications 20211009-AL-003 and 20211010-AL-001).

The arrival of this CME was detected by DSCOVR and ACE at L1 on 2021-10-12T01:46Z (see notification 20211012-AL-003) and STEREO A around 2021-10-12T12:30Z. 

The second C-type CME was first seen in SOHO LASCO C2 starting at 2021-10-12T03:24Z. It was estimated that the leading edge or flank of the CME will reach STEREO B at 2021-10-15T05:39Z and Solar Orbiter at 2021-10-14T19:00Z (plus minus 7 hours). The simulation also indicated that the CME might have a glancing blow at NASA missions near Earth at about 2021-10-15T12:00Z (plus minus 7 hours). The roughly estimated expected range of the maximum Kp index is 2-3 (below minor) (see notification 20211012-AL-005).

Geomagnetic activity was at moderate levels with Kp index (a measure of geomagnetic activity, ranging 0-9) <=6 for the reporting period. The highest value of Kp = 6 occurred during the synoptic periods of 2021-10-12T03:00Z-06:00Z and 2021-10-12T09:00Z-12:00Z. These elevated values of Kp were caused by the significant interplanetary shock detected by DSCOVR and ACE at L1 at 2021-10-12T01:46Z associated with the arrival of the CME first visible on 2021-10-09T07:09Z (see notifications 20211012-AL-001, 20211012-AL-003, and 20211012-AL-004).

Additionally, DSCOVR and ACE detected the arrival at L1 on 2021-10-06T10:26Z of the CME first visible in SOHO LASCO C2 on 2021-10-01T16:12Z.  Another arrival was detected on 2021-10-10T12:01Z due to a coronal hole high speed stream. 

The > 2.0 MeV energetic electron flux detected at GOES remained below the threshold level of 1000 pfu for the entire reporting period. 

The flux of 13-100 MeV protons at STEREO A exceeded 10^(-1) pfu/MeV starting at 2021-10-09T07:51Z (see notifications 20211009-AL-001 and 20211009-AL-002). The energetic proton flux of >10 MeV protons detected at GOES were slightly elevated starting at 2021-10-09T15:00Z, but remained below the threshold of 10 pfu for the reporting period. These elevated proton levels were associated with the M1.6 class flare and the associated C-type CME.

Space Weather Impact:
Space weather impacts on NASA spacecraft are expected to have been low to moderate this week due to the solar energetic particle event described above.
